Large Fire in Baltimore.; A fire broke out in this city at 6 o'clock this evening, on the north side of Baltimore-street, between Eutaw and Paca-streets, in JOHN McGOWAN'S liquor warehouse. The names soon spread from there to six adjoining buildings, each four stories high, occupied by the following named persons:

LATEST INTELLIGENCE; By Telegraph to the New-York Daily Times FROM WASHINGTON. Interesting Rumors--Founded and Unfounded, &c.
Front Page 2 -- No Title
The Express Office at Kenton, Ohio, was robbed of $475 on Wednesday night last, by the safe being opened by a white man and a negro. They were traced to Dayton, and $400 of the money found. A large Tobacco Factory on Twenty-second-street, Richmond, Va., was destroyed by fire on Friday night.

Article 4 -- No Title
Is Coal our only Fuel?; There never comes a rain that deluges a village but somebody's potato patch is improved by it. And the exerbitant charges for Coal that speculating, and--if we may be allowed the expression-injudicious dealers have stock us with, will not be without some good results.

Liverpool Markets. Per Pacific.] LIVERPOOL, Tuesday, April 18, 1851. We have no new feature in our COTTON Market worthy of much notice, a slightly improved tone having been apparent the last tow days, though with the increased business there is in some few quarters a determination to realize, and occasional low sales have been made.; By Telegraph to the New Fork Dailp Times. FRANCE.; The Austre-Prussian Treaty--Five Conscripts out of one Family--Alexander Dumas-??--Res-bif and God-dem.
THE STREET-PREACHING EXCITEMENT.; Street-Preaching in New-York. THE ANGEL GABRIEL AND MRS. BISHOP. A good deal of excitement existed in the City yesterday relative to the street-preaching, some riots being anticipated as the result of last Sunday's scenes in Brooklyn. We are happy to record, however, that everything went off quietly. Towards 3 o'clock numbers of people gathered from Broadway and Bowery] to the Park, which in half an hour was crowded in front of the City Hall steps.

THIRTY-THIRD CONGRESS.....First Session.; SENATE. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. IT IS STRENGTHENED BY ORDER. THE SAN FRANCISCO SUFFERERS. PRIVATE BILLS. MR. SOLLERS IS MAGNANIMOUS. TWO LINES OF SPECIMEN REPORTING. MR. SOLLERS SAYS "AH!" MR. LANE IS STERN. MR. ORR DID SOMETHING. AND IS INVITED TO SIT DOWN. MR. SOLLERS IS NOT A MOULDER. QUIET IS RESTORED. THEY GO AT IT AGAIN. LONG THEY ARE DOING IT. THEY WAX FUNNY.

Article 8 -- No Title
Breaking up of the Ice.
CELEBRATION OF ST. PATRICK'S DAY.--The Convention of Irish Societies met last night at No. 76 Prince-street. The route of the procession for that day formed the chief object of discussion, and it was at length arranged to appoint a Committee to wait on Col. FERRIS, of the 9th Regiment, to ascertain what route the military would take, in order that the civic societies might fall in after them."
OPENING OF ALBANY-STREET.; Argument of Mr. P. Y. Cutler before the Committee.

SPECIAL NOTICES.
NOVEL MARRIAGE.--The Fort Smith, Ark., Herald relates the following: "The other day, the sedate clerk of our court-room was sitting at his desk busily engaged in writing, when a gentleman from the country, about 50 years of age, and a lady not far behind in this respect, entered the office, and after the usual salutations, the man asked him a few questions about the law on contracts, and wished to know what marriage was considered, legally.

MARRIED.
PROGRESS OF THE CRYSTAL PALACE AT SYDENHAM.--The Crystal Palace Company are progressing bravely with their great work. They have voted the raising of [pound]250,000 more money, marking [pound]1,000,000 in all. They are letting their space fast at 7s. 6d. to 60s. a square foot; in one instance [pound]500 has been given for a plot of space 8 feet by 8, and they have given up the idea of erecting a monster organ, of which we some weeks since showed the absurdity.

Article 3 -- No Title
Information for the Benefit of Emigrants.
The new Mayor of Philadelphia is reported as having been very successful yesterday in his effort to close the groggeries of the city on the Sabbath. The "letting customers in at the back door" was tried by some, as was to be expected.

Front Page 1 -- No Title
NEW-YORK CITY.; an a Part Owner of Goods Commit Barratry in respect to them ? Liability of Railroad Companies. Important Decisions. SUPERIOR COURT--SPECIAL TERM. UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT.
The Albany Atlas gives premonitory symptoms of going for the reestablishment of the African Slave-trade. It endorses the opinion of the Rochester Union. that there is nothing in the Constitution or in the law of nations forbidding it, and adds on its own account, that the existing prohibition of the traffic "acts as a prohibitory system of protection to the Northern range of Slave State which export Slaves to the further South.

THE VERY LATEST.; Highly Important. SPECIALLY TELEGRAPHED.
Midsummer Night's Dream--Letter from Mr. Davidge.
The Canal Vote.
YELLOW FEVER AT PORT AU PRINCE.--Accounts received yesterday morning from the above port, to Jan. 19, report the fever as raging, particularly among the shipping. Among the deaths we notice that of Captain BROWN, of the brig Industry, and the Captains of the brig Loango, from Philadelphia, and of the schooner King Phillip, from Boston, and from two to four men from each of the above vessels.

MARINE INTELLIGENCE.
A More Strict Enforcement of the Passenger Laws, and Censequent Saving of Life.
Mysterious Death--Suspected Poisoning.; For several days past, rumors of a painful character have been in circulation in Syracuse, in reference to the mysterious illness of Mrs. ELLEN URBON, a daughter of Mr. C. MARVIN, No. 50 Warren-street. It seems that nearly two years ago Mrs. E., then aged about 16, was married to a German music teacher, ALEXANDER URBON, in this city, and subsequently went with him to Leroy, Genesee County, to reside.

SOUTHERN SENTIMENT.
Arrival of the Pampere at New-Orleans.
Explosion of a Locomotive--Three Men Killed.
Article 3 -- No Title
ALLEGED FRAUD.--A case of alleged fraud upon a wealthy lady named Ruth Ann Ross, has been brought before Judge Stuart, at the Jefferson Police Court. The aggregate amount involved is said to be twenty-six thousand dollars. The complainant details, under oath, the particulars of the operation, in substance as follows: On or about the 14th of December last, she had an interview with a male acquaintance, who assumed and stated that he was the owner of leases, fixtures, bonds, furniture and other property belonging to a City Hotel, which was doing business amounting annually to he net profit of $25,000.

BANK NOTICES.
BOILER EXPLOSION.--At 1 3/4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the three boilers attached to the engine in the large foundry establishment of CAMERON, MUSTARD & Co., at the east end of Hasell -street, exploded with a noise that alarmed and shocked the residents in that section of the city to a considerable distance.

BANK NOTICES.
Letter from Colonel Forney.
The Egyptian Railroad is in good working order, and answers exceedingly well. The trains do not run on it at present at any stated periods. It is chiefly used when European or Indian passenger arrive in Egypt. English engine drivers are employed on it. The speed in about 20 miles an hour. The railway the whole distance between Alexandria and Cairo will soon be oven.

Article 8 -- No Title
Haudseine Compliment to Captain Iugraham.; "PRESENTED TO CAPTAIN INGRAHAM, Of the United States Navy,
Owing to the lateness of the hour at which our Congressional reports are, of late, concluded, we are unable to give as full a summary as in desirable. The most interesting features yesterday were the reports of the Committee appointed to investigate the alterations made in the Minnesota Land bill and the report of the act.
